text: You'd think the marketplace would balance pretty quickly. You'd think, okay, maybe these people will start moving to other jobs, but it wasn't happening. A large reason behind this, people are used to looking for certain particular titles, and they didn't start realizing other people could do this job.
speaker: Hari Srinivasan
context: Lenny asks Hari what changes he's seeing in the hiring market. Hari is describing the situation during COVID when hospitality workers were losing jobs while customer service couldn't hire enough people. Despite the obvious mismatch, the marketplace wasn't self-correcting because people were too focused on job titles rather than transferable skills.
text_ko: 사람들은 보통 시장(marketplace)이 금방 균형을 맞출 거라고 생각해요. '아마 사람들이 다른 직무로 옮기겠지'라고들 예상하지만, 실제로는 그렇지 않았어요. 큰 이유 중 하나는 사람들이 특정 직함(title)만 찾아보는 데 익숙해서 다른 사람이 그 일을 할 수 있다는 걸 잘 인식하지 못했기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 你会觉得市场应该很快就能平衡了，对吧？你会想，好吧，也许这些人会开始跳槽去别的工作，但实际上并没有发生。这背后很大一个原因是，大家都习惯了盯着某些特定的职位头衔，没有意识到其实别人也能干这个活儿。
text_es: Uno pensaría que el mercado se equilibraría bastante rápido. Pensarías, bueno, tal vez esta gente empezaría a moverse a otros trabajos, pero no estaba pasando. Una gran razón detrás de esto es que la gente está acostumbrada a buscar ciertos títulos específicos, y no se dieron cuenta de que otras personas podían hacer ese trabajo.
key_sentence: People didn't start realizing others could do their job.

text: We made a pretty big push in something we call skills-first hiring. This was the idea that we could translate people's experiences into a set of skills, and by that we could help them really start balancing the marketplace with a much different system.
speaker: Hari Srinivasan
context: Hari continues explaining LinkedIn's response to the COVID hiring crisis. Skills-first hiring is LinkedIn's approach where they translate people's work experiences into transferable skills rather than focusing on specific job titles. This allows workers to be matched with roles they might not have considered but have the necessary skills for.
text_ko: 우리는 '역량 중심 채용 (skills-first hiring)'을 적극적으로 추진했어요. 사람들의 경험을 스킬 세트(skill set)로 환산해서, 그렇게 해서 전혀 다른 방식의 시스템으로 인재 시장(marketplace)의 균형을 맞추는 데 실제로 도움이 될 수 있다는 생각이었어요.
text_zh: 我们在技能优先招聘(skills-first hiring)这块下了很大功夫。就是说我们能把人的经历转化成一套技能体系，这样就能帮他们用一套完全不同的系统来平衡市场。
text_es: Hicimos una apuesta bastante fuerte en algo que llamamos contratación basada en habilidades (skills-first hiring). La idea era que podíamos convertir las experiencias de la gente en un conjunto de competencias, y así ayudarles a equilibrar realmente el mercado laboral con un sistema completamente diferente.
key_sentence: We made a pretty big push for skills-first hiring, balancing the marketplace.

text: I think that the job market is rebalancing, but it's being done, the pathways are being done in a very different way that seems to be maybe a change that holds through these ups and downs. That'll be very interesting to see.
speaker: Hari Srinivasan
context: Lenny asks about changes in the hiring market, and Hari explains that while the job market is shifting back toward employers having more power, some fundamental changes from the pandemic era are persisting. He believes the new pathways for job searching - like skills-based matching and values-based job seeking - represent lasting changes rather than temporary shifts.
vocabulary_highlights: holds through these ups and downs
text_ko: 고용 시장이 재균형을 찾아가는 것 같아요. 그런데 그 과정이나 경로가 훨씬 다른 방식으로 움직이고 있어서, 이런 변화가 경기의 오르내림을 겪어도 계속 유지될 변화인 것 같아요. 그게 어떻게 전개될지 지켜보는 게 정말 흥미로울 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得就业市场正在重新找平衡，但是这个过程啊，走的路子跟以前很不一样，感觉这个变化可能会一直持续下去，不管市场怎么起起伏伏。这个还挺有意思的，值得继续观察。
text_es: Creo que el mercado laboral se está reequilibrando, pero se está haciendo de una manera muy distinta, los caminos están cambiando de una forma que parece que va a mantenerse a pesar de los altibajos. Va a ser muy interesante ver qué pasa.
key_sentence: The job market is rebalancing, holding through these ups and downs.

text: When you were just looking at title, I think you only had one way to really prove that you had the skills. You had to have that title, which is very hard to break in. In a world where you're looking at skills, you can go through and say, 'Look, I can do these things and you could put evidence behind it.'
speaker: Hari Srinivasan
context: Lenny asks for tips on how product managers can improve their chances of being found by recruiters. Hari is explaining how LinkedIn's skills-first approach creates new opportunities for job seekers. Previously, candidates needed specific job titles to prove their capabilities, but now they can demonstrate relevant skills through various forms of evidence and credentials.
text_ko: 예전엔 직함(title)만 보고 판단하니까 실력을 제대로 증명할 방법이 사실상 하나밖에 없었어요. 그 직함을 가져야 했고, 그걸 얻기가 정말 어려웠죠. 그런데 이제는 실력을 보고 평가하는 쪽이라서 “제가 이런 일을 할 수 있고, 그걸 증빙할 자료도 있어요”라고 보여줄 수 있어요.
text_zh: 以前光看头衔的时候，我觉得你要证明自己有能力就只有一条路，就是必须得有那个头衔，但这个门槛特别难跨过去。现在这个看重技能的时代就不一样了，你可以直接说"你看，这些事儿我都能干"，而且还能拿出实实在在的证据来证明。
text_es: Cuando solo se fijaban en el título, creo que solo tenías una manera de demostrar realmente que tenías las habilidades. Tenías que tener ese título, y meterte ahí es súper difícil. En un mundo donde se fijan en las habilidades, puedes llegar y decir: "Mira, yo sé hacer estas cosas y te puedo dar pruebas de ello."
key_sentence: It's very hard to break in when only titles prove skills.

text: I just remember driving home and calling my wife and like, 'I think I might be fired.' I'm not sure if I was fired, but he was very kind about it. He's like, 'Just come back and exit.' I think five, four weeks.
speaker: Hari Srinivasan
context: Lenny asks Hari about his first product review at LinkedIn after joining through an acquisition. Hari describes how he got 'destroyed' during his first presentation because he had relied too heavily on generic advice rather than understanding LinkedIn's core mission. This moment of potential failure led to a pivotal learning experience about focusing on the company's North Star.
text_ko: 집으로 운전해 가던 길에 아내한테 전화해서 "나 아마 해고된 것 같아"라고 했던 게 기억나요. 진짜 해고된 건지는 확실하지 않아요. 근데 그분이 되게 친절하게 대해주셨어요. "그냥 다시 와서 퇴사 처리하면 돼요"라고 하시더라고요. 아마 네다섯 주 정도였던 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我记得开车回家的时候给我老婆打电话，我说"我觉得我可能被炒了。"我也不确定是不是真的被开了，但他人还挺好的。他说"你回来办个离职手续就行。"我想是五周，还是四周来着。
text_es: Recuerdo que iba manejando a casa y le marqué a mi esposa y le dije, 'Creo que me corrieron.' No estaba seguro si me habían despedido, pero él fue muy gentil al respecto. Me dijo algo como, 'Solo regresa y termina tu proceso de salida.' Creo que fueron cinco, cuatro semanas.
key_sentence: I think I might be fired, but he was kind about it.

text: I think when people ask me to describe LinkedIn, I often start with that story because I feel like it helps cut through how decisions are made and what is seen as success here.
speaker: Hari Srinivasan
context: Hari continues reflecting on his difficult first product review at LinkedIn. He's explaining how this experience taught him about LinkedIn's decision-making culture and North Star of connecting people to economic opportunity. Despite LinkedIn being a complex company with multiple business lines, this clear mission helps cut through complexity when making product decisions.
text_ko: 사람들이 저한테 LinkedIn을 설명해 달라고 물어보면, 저는 보통 그 이야기를 먼저 꺼내요. 그게 여기서 의사결정이 어떻게 이뤄지는지와 무엇을 성공으로 보는지를 더 잘 보여주거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得当别人让我介绍LinkedIn的时候，我经常会从那个故事开始讲，因为我感觉这样能让大家更清楚地了解我们这里是怎么做决策的，什么才算是成功。
text_es: Cuando me preguntan cómo describiría LinkedIn, casi siempre empiezo con esa historia porque siento que ayuda a entender realmente cómo se toman las decisiones aquí y qué consideramos un éxito.
key_sentence: That story helps cut through how decisions are made.

text: I do think it's exceptional leadership, and I've learned so much from watching it and how it gets operated. I do think the culture has a pretty high immune system now in the sense that when you aren't operating by that, people can see it and they operate against it.
speaker: Hari Srinivasan
context: Lenny asks how LinkedIn operationalizes its North Star of connecting people to economic opportunity. Hari explains that it comes from consistent repetition by leadership over many years. The concept of a 'high immune system' refers to how the culture now automatically rejects decisions or behaviors that don't align with the core mission.
text_ko: 정말 탁월한 리더십이라고 생각해요. 지켜보면서 리더십이 어떻게 발휘되고 운영되는지도 많이 배웠어요. 조직 문화에는 이제 꽤 강한 면역 체계(immune system)가 있어서, 그 방식대로 운영하지 않으면 사람들이 금방 알아차리고 거기에 맞서 행동해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这真的是很了不起的领导力，我通过观察学到了很多，看他们是怎么运作的。我觉得现在这个企业文化已经有了很强的免疫力，就是说如果你不按这套来，大家一眼就能看出来，而且会自然地去纠正。
text_es: Sí creo que es un liderazgo excepcional, y he aprendido muchísimo viendo cómo funciona y cómo se maneja. Creo que la cultura ya tiene un sistema inmunológico bastante fuerte en el sentido de que cuando no estás operando así, la gente se da cuenta y actúa en contra.
key_sentence: The culture has a pretty high immune system against poor leadership.
